author: Georgia Today
title: Italian Conductor Beatrice Venezi Shines at Georgia's "Night Serenades" Festival - Georgia Today
text:
In a dazzling display of musical talent and cultural exchange, Italian conductor Beatrice Venezi has brought her exceptional artistry to Georgia as part of the renowned ‚ÄúNight Serenades‚Äù festival. Founded in 1982 by the celebrated Georgian violinist Liana Isakadze with the support of the Italian Embassy in Georgia, this international music festival has been a significant cultural event, and Venezi‚Äôs participation underscores its continued prominence.
The ‚ÄúNight Serenades‚Äù festival, which has become a cornerstone of Georgia‚Äôs cultural landscape, has recently featured a series of remarkable concerts. Following two impressive performances in Batumi and Borjomi by the esteemed Italian accordionist Mario Stefano Pietrodarchi, the festival‚Äôs grand finale was held at the Tbilisi State Conservatoire, with Beatrice Venezi as the centerpiece of the event.
Beatrice Venezi‚Äôs career is a testament to her exceptional talent and influence in the world of classical music. With a background in piano, composition, and conducting from the Milan Conservatory of Music ‚ÄúGiuseppe Verdi,‚Äù she has held prominent positions, including Advisor to the Italian Minister of Culture for Music and Artistic Director of the Taormina Arte Foundation at the Ancient Theatre of Taormina. Her previous roles also include Principal Guest Conductor of the Orchestra della Toscana, Principal Conductor of the Orchestra Milano Classica, and Principal Conductor of the Orchestra Scarlatti Young. Her involvement as Principal Guest Conductor of the Puccini Festival in Torre del Lago further highlights her esteemed position in the classical music arena.
Venezi‚Äôs global reach includes collaborations with prestigious orchestras such as the Orchestra del Teatro La Fenice, the Orchestra del Maggio Musicale Fiorentino, and the New Japan Philharmonic. Her extensive performance history, comprising over 160 symphony concerts and 50 opera performances, underscores her versatility and dedication.
Reflecting on her role in the ‚ÄúNight Serenades‚Äù festival, Venezi noted the unique challenges and opportunities of performing in different cultural contexts. ‚ÄúYes, it can be quite a challenge because there are so many differences related to musical culture. The way of performing certain pieces and the taste for certain music can vary widely,‚Äù she observed. Despite these challenges, she expressed her enthusiasm for sharing Italian music with Georgian audiences. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very happy to bring Italian music here,‚Äù she added, highlighting the importance of cultural exchange and her role in bridging musical traditions.
A significant aspect of Venezi‚Äôs work is her commitment to advancing female leadership in the arts. She remarked, ‚ÄúWhen we talk about leadership, we often think of a man. This happens in many countries, including Italy. It was surprising to me because Italy is in the heart of Europe. There are significant differences between Southern and Northern Europe.‚Äù Her advocacy for gender equality is reflected in her preference for using the term ‚Äúconductor,‚Äù which she views as a gender-neutral designation. ‚ÄúI want the role to be defined by skill and not by gender,‚Äù she explained, emphasizing her belief in merit-based recognition.
Venezi‚Äôs innovative approach to classical music includes a focus on blending different musical styles to attract new audiences. She believes that integrating classical music with genres such as jazz or soundtracks can rejuvenate interest in the genre and engage a broader audience. ‚ÄúClassical music is sometimes perceived as boring or outdated, but we need to open our minds and explore how to attract new audiences to this genre. Mixing classical music with other styles can be beneficial and help engage new listeners,‚Äù she said.
Her experience in Georgia, particularly at the Tbilisi State Conservatoire, has been marked by warm hospitality and enthusiastic audiences. Reflecting on her time in Tbilisi, Venezi shared, ‚ÄúThe hospitality has been great, and the audience is very warm. I really enjoy Tbilisi. I remember my first visit in 2016 or 2017 when I performed at the Opera House. I had the chance to explore and experience the beauty of the country. I always look forward to coming back here, as I feel at home.‚Äù Her fondness for Georgia highlights the meaningful connections she has made and the cultural richness she has encountered.

title: I lavoratori di Amazon in pi\u00f9 di 20 paesi protesteranno durante il Black Friday e il Cyber \u200b\u200bMonday, dicono gli organizzatori
text:
Secondo gli organizzatori, i lavoratori di Amazon in pi√π di 20 paesi, tra cui Stati Uniti e Regno Unito, hanno in programma di organizzare proteste o scioperare tra il Black Friday e il Cyber Monday, due delle principali promozioni di shopping dell‚Äôanno.
Le previste manifestazioni ‚ÄúMake Amazon Pay‚Äù hanno lo scopo di ‚Äúritenere Amazon responsabile degli abusi sul lavoro, del degrado ambientale e delle minacce alla democrazia‚Äù, secondo gli organizzatori dell‚Äôiniziativa, la federazione del lavoro con sede in Svizzera UNI Global Union e il gruppo di attivisti di base Progressive International.
‚ÄúSiamo uniti nel chiedere che Amazon tratti i suoi lavoratori in modo equo, rispetti i diritti fondamentali e smetta di indebolire i sistemi destinati a proteggere tutti noi. ‚ÄúMake Amazon Pay Day‚Äù sta diventando un atto globale di resistenza contro l‚Äôabuso di potere di Amazon‚Äù, ha affermato Christy Hoffman, segretaria generale di UNI Global Union.
In una dichiarazione, la portavoce di Amazon Eileen Hards ha dichiarato: ‚ÄúQuesti gruppi rappresentano una variet√† di interessi e, mentre ascoltiamo sempre e cerchiamo modi per migliorare, rimaniamo orgogliosi della retribuzione competitiva, dei vantaggi completi e dell'esperienza lavorativa coinvolgente e sicura‚Äù. forniamo ai nostri team‚Äù.
I due organizzatori dello sciopero hanno affermato che i sindacati e i gruppi alleati stanno pianificando di organizzare manifestazioni negli Stati Uniti, nel Regno Unito, in Germania, Francia, Giappone, Brasile, Turchia e in altre nazioni. In almeno sei citt√† tedesche, migliaia di lavoratori di Amazon sono pronti a scioperare. A Nuova Delhi, centinaia di lavoratori di Amazon dovrebbero manifestarsi per chiedere un trattamento equo.
La prevista ‚Äúgiornata globale della resistenza‚Äù arriva mentre i leader sindacali di tutto il mondo si sentono sempre pi√π incoraggiati ad affrontare le grandi aziende in un‚Äôera di disuguaglianza di reddito. L‚ÄôOrganizzazione Internazionale del Lavoro, un braccio delle Nazioni Unite, ha scoperto che l‚Äôinflazione post-pandemia e l‚Äôaumento del costo della vita hanno eroso il valore reale dei salari minimi in molti paesi.
Negli ultimi anni, gli attivisti sindacali americani hanno indirizzato sempre pi√π la loro ira su Amazon e sul fondatore miliardario del colosso dello shopping, Jeff Bezos. I risultati sono stati contrastanti. All‚Äôinizio del 2022, una struttura Amazon a Staten Island, New York, √® diventata il primo magazzino aziendale a votare per formare un sindacato. Ma simili iniziative sindacali in Alabama e in almeno altri due a New York fallirono.
Non √® stato immediatamente chiaro quanti lavoratori di Amazon negli Stati Uniti avrebbero partecipato alle manifestazioni annunciate contro l‚Äôazienda con sede a Seattle, una delle principali aziende di e-commerce e tecnologia digitale al mondo.
‚ÄúAmazzonia √® ovunque, ma lo siamo anche noi‚Äù, ha affermato Varsha Gandikota-Nellutla, co-coordinatrice generale di Progressive International. ‚ÄúUnendo i nostri movimenti oltre i confini, non solo possiamo costringere Amazon a cambiare i suoi modi, ma gettare le basi di un mondo che d√† priorit√† alla dignit√† umana, non al saldo bancario di Jeff Bezos‚Äù.
UNI Global Union e Progressive International hanno affermato che questo √® il quinto anno di attivit√† ‚ÄúMake Amazon Pay‚Äù. Negli anni precedenti, secondo i gruppi, migliaia di lavoratori hanno scioperato negli stabilimenti aziendali in Germania, Francia, Spagna, Regno Unito e Italia.

author: Elizabeth Weitzman
title: ‚ÄòSlingshot‚Äô Review: In Space, No One Can Hear You Yawn
text:
This summer we‚Äôve celebrated the 45th anniversary of ‚ÄúAlien‚Äù and the 15th anniversary of ‚ÄúMoon,‚Äù two of the greatest stuck-in-space films ever made. We‚Äôve also been watching a related plot play out in reality, as Boeing‚Äôs ill-fated Starliner has left astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore idling at the International Space Station.
So perhaps at another time, Mikael H√•fstr√∂m‚Äôs ‚ÄúSlingshot‚Äù would get a pass for effort, if nothing else.
This is, admittedly, a challenging genre. But given its provocative potential (and H√•fstr√∂m‚Äôs repeated references to Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs all-time interstellar icon, ‚Äú2001: A Space Odyssey‚Äù), a halfhearted take feels particularly disappointing.
The film‚Äôs listless energy begins with John (Casey Affleck), an astronaut years into his mission to Titan, Saturn‚Äôs largest moon. For someone trapped in a metal capsule, John initially appears to be doing ok. But when his ground commander (David Morrissey) checks in ‚Äúto stress the importance of your psych evaluation,‚Äù we‚Äôve got a pretty clear idea where things are headed.
There are only two other people aboard the Odyssey: John‚Äôs colleague Nash (Tomer Capone) and their captain, Franks (Laurence Fishburne). So it‚Äôs a little odd that John and Nash are continually required to cycle in and out of a drug-induced hypersleep. Stranger still, they wake up each time feeling increasingly confused and paranoid. Although ‚Ä¶ is it paranoia if you might be right?
Read Next
‚ÄòThe Deliverance‚Äô Review: Andra Day Soars but the Devil Disappoints in Lee Daniels‚Äô Exorcism Thriller For starters, when the capsule is damaged and a panicked Nash notes the dangers in continuing their mission, Franks shuts him down with suspicious speed. As Nash pushes for an insurrection and Franks prepares to fight back, a disoriented John is stuck in the middle, unsure of who he should trust.
It‚Äôs no wonder, then, that each time he goes back to ‚Äúsleep,‚Äù he returns to the comfort of pre-launch memories. Mostly, he thinks about his girlfriend Zoe (Emily Beecham), who also works for the space program. He warned her early on that he didn‚Äôt have time for a relationship, as he was hoping to be chosen for this mission. But when they fell in love, he surprised himself by the depth of their connection. We, unfortunately, are less convinced. These flashbacks are both underdeveloped and overlong, which only emphasizes how little chemistry there is between Affleck and Beecham. She seems uncomfortable, and he just seems bored.
Affleck‚Äôs disaffection carries through almost every scene ‚Äî until the very end. For this is, as it turns out, one of those movies that relies so heavily on its final twist that the rest of the story becomes an afterthought. Affleck, H√•fstr√∂m (‚Äú1408‚Äù), and screenwriters R. Scott Adams (‚ÄúDonner Pass‚Äù) and Nathan Parker (who co-wrote the infinitely superior ‚ÄúMoon‚Äù) seem so sure our minds will eventually be blown, they‚Äôre simply connecting dots until they can scribble madly across the page. Not everyone got the memo, though, so the actors often appear to be in different movies.
Affleck‚Äôs scenes tend to be long and quiet, but he‚Äôs so unemotive they mostly feel inert. A jumpy Capone (‚ÄúFauda‚Äù) and intense Fishburne work overtime to add energy, but they‚Äôre stuck in a thriller with few thrills, while Affleck and Beecham seem to be in a drama with little drama.
Similarly, Steffen Thum‚Äôs portentous score tries to build some menace, but ultimately has nowhere to go. Until, of course, that final scene, towards which we‚Äôve been hurtling since the start. The good news is that the ending really is as strong as the filmmakers believe. And since H√•fstr√∂m and his crew stick their landing, those who particularly enjoy second-hand claustrophobia may find it worth the long journey. Everyone else, however, will be better served by more engaging enterprises here on Earth.
